title: SimplyMargotL
author: SimplyMargotL
content: As more countries launch their own central bank digital currencies, will bitcoin face increased attacks? Could a mass push for CBDSc lead to restrictions on bitcoin or will btc remain a global alternative?

comments.author: KiaKia
comments.body: They were too consumed with the belief that Bitcoin wouldn't survive, questioning, "Who is going to buy it anyway?" Ironically, they are now the ones helping to protect Bitcoin. It's too late for them; a few countries still hold power, yet billions of dollars worth of Bitcoin are backing numerous popular companies globally. The world reserve system is evolving, and banks will soon join the fray. As you can see, it's already too late for those opposed to Bitcoin.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: The War on Bitcoin is a never stopping war and it changes over time. At first they may have wanted to "kill" Bitcoin but they eventually learned they cannot kill something decentralized (same way they could never kill torrent network or Tor).So their restrictions began, we saw bans, we saw regulations, we saw a whole lot of crazy things.In the future there is a higher chance they'd want to "control" Bitcoin. Taking control could mean heavy regulations where they force people to use centralized services when they want to use bitcoin. Whether it is through ETFs forcing people to only invest in bitcoin instead of using it and do it only through ETFs, or whether it is through custodial wallets they governments issue and control!

comments.author: apogio
comments.body: Everything pooya87 said, plus one more possible unethical attack:they could try to DDOS some websites that facilitate our lives when using decentralised services.they could cause massive fear to the average person through the media.they could penalise more people like the samourai wallet's developers, making examples out of them, in order to scare other people.

comments.author: BenCodie
comments.body: I do believe that there will be ramifications for Bitcoin should CBDC be implemented with full interoperability with Bitcoin and the wider market. Though, if CBDCs introduce normal people to a technology that operates similarly to Bitcoin, they'd inadvertently be giving people practical experience of how the Blockchain works, how to do transactions, and validating the overall concept that Bitcoin started, inevitably leading to people researching what came first, which inevitably leads to a switch to Bitcoin. CBDCs may not be good in the interim, but they may be good for adoption in the long term in my opinion.
